conclusion: Analyze the forces on the equilateral triangular conductor frame in the magnetic field.

The equilateral triangle is composed of uniform resistance wires; points A and B are connected to a power supply with a constant voltage; the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the triangle.
Ampere's Force Law: The force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is given by F = I · L · B · sin(θ).
Since the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the triangle, θ = 90°, and sin(90°) = 1.
The current I is distributed equally among the three sides of the equilateral triangle.
Let the current through each side be I/3.
The force on each side of the triangle is F = (I/3) · L · B.
The force on side AB is given as F.
The forces on sides AC and BC are also F each, but they are directed at angles to the horizontal.
The forces on sides AC and BC can be resolved into horizontal and vertical components.
The horizontal components of the forces on AC and BC cancel each other out.
The vertical components add up to give the resultant force.
The vertical component of the force on each side is F · sin(60°).
Since sin(60°) = √3/2, the vertical component of each force is F · √3/2.
The total vertical force is 2 · F · √3/2 = F · √3.
The resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is F · √3.
